pullRequest.body:
- Reduce the `linarith` certificate search problem to some Linear Programming problem and implement the Simplex Algorithm to solve it. 
- Set the default oracle for `linarith` to this.
- Remove unnecessary hypotheses in `Mathlib/Analysis/Calculus/BumpFunction/FiniteDimension.lean` and `Mathlib/Analysis/Distribution/SchwartzSpace.lean` which were needed with the Fourier-Motzkin oracle.
- Adjust the definition of `CerficateOracle` to enable dot notation to choose between oracles.

This addresses #2717 and #8875 (except when the user overrides the oracle)

Also, this oracle is far more efficient:
The example below takes lots of time with the Fourier-Motzkin oracle: I waited 5 minutes and still didn't get it. But with the just implemented `Linarith.SimplexAlgo.produceCertificate` oracle the proof succeeds in less than a second.
```lean
import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith

example (x0 x1 x2 x3 x4 : ℚ) :
  3 * x0 - 15 * x1 - 30 * x2 + 20 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  35 * x0 - 30 * x1 + 12 * x2 - 15 * x3 + 18 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  5 * x0 + 20 * x1 + 24 * x2 + 20 * x3 + 9 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -2 * x0 - 30 * x1 + 30 * x2 - 10 * x3 - 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -4 * x0 - 25 * x1 + 6 * x2 - 20 * x3 ≤ 0 →
  25 * x1 + 30 * x2 - 25 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  10 * x1 - 18 * x2 - 30 * x3 + 18 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  4 * x0 + 10 * x1 - 18 * x2 - 15 * x3 + 15 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -4 * x0 + 15 * x1 - 30 * x2 + 15 * x3 + 6 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -2 * x0 - 5 * x1 + 18 * x2 - 25 * x3 - 161 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -6 * x0 + 30 * x1 + 6 * x2 - 15 * x3 ≤ 0 →
  3 * x0 + 10 * x1 - 30 * x2 + 25 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  2 * x0 + 10 * x1 - 24 * x2 - 15 * x3 + 3 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  82 * x1 + 36 * x2 + 20 * x3 + 9 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  2 * x0 - 30 * x1 - 30 * x2 - 15 * x3 + 6 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  4 * x0 - 15 * x1 + 25 * x2 < 0 →
  -4 * x0 - 10 * x1 + 30 * x2 - 15 * x3 ≤ 0 →
  2 * x0 + 6 * x2 + 133 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  3 * x0 + 15 * x1 - 6 * x2 - 15 * x3 - 15 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  10 * x1 + 6 * x2 - 25 * x3 + 3 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -2 * x0 + 5 * x1 + 12 * x2 - 20 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -5 * x0 - 25 * x1 + 30 * x3 - 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  -6 * x0 - 30 * x1 - 36 * x2 + 20 * x3 + 12 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  5 * x0 - 5 * x1 + 6 * x2 - 25 * x3 ≤ 0 →
  -3 * x0 - 20 * x1 - 30 * x2 + 5 * x3 + 3 * x4 ≤ 0 →
  False := by intros; linarith (config := {oracle := Linarith.FourierMotzkin.produceCertificate})
```

I am planning to prove the "completeness" of the oracle in the next PRs, but so far I have run a stress test on randomly generated examples of various sizes, and it seems that everything is OK.

---

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/d6dba336-dfc2-47c4-936c-3a8e39b4d643) for commit 5567bbab2358d186b8c6112c563d53d0e80b78e4.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/222ede96-142a-4958-b25d-37ba701cf6e0/to/d6dba336-dfc2-47c4-936c-3a8e39b4d643) against commit 1c351ac79b7648b78036f6e437c53a883ded4a7b:
```diff
  Benchmark                                  Metric         Change
  ================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.AddCircle   instructions   -65.0%
```

At first glance this looks great! Could you add the examples from the two issues this closes as test cases in the `test` directory? Simply creating them is enough for them to be picked up as tests.

It's unfortunate that over mathlib as a whole this has almost no performance impact (besides the outlier `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.AddCircle`), but perhaps it only makes a difference on very large states; certainly this is not an argument *against* this PR :)
@eric-wieser Thank you for your feedback! I have addressed your comments and slightly revised the code, making it shorter and (I hope) easier to read.
Any further review comments? I think we can get this in soon.

I pushed some changes to avoid putting the `SimplexAlgorithm` stuff in a file about `FourierMotzkin`, and to make it slightly more ergonomic to switch between the two.

I added a test that shows that actually in some cases the new algorithm is worse; though I think these are relatively rare.
bors d=@semorrison

:v: semorrison can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/8695295a-9373-4b99-8648-a716c5a27c59) for commit 58116f50298993098c7ee87d21f0e12d30b4aa1b.
The entire run failed.
Found no significant differences.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/ea6e774a-0e67-4b35-b0d1-eaeee9799d15) for commit 6bff856be980fbc2354e3031d74d6085b01663e3.
The entire run failed.
Found no significant differences.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/6d2210f1-008f-4d4b-abd4-7b136a3e2f91) for commit 18974fc3dc250ebf36f92fc6bfc277b3d25c26cc.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/89419e40-71d2-424d-bd5f-405926538016/to/6d2210f1-008f-4d4b-abd4-7b136a3e2f91) against commit 78e447bdfc00bfd482f142cd02b41ebdede3a8f5:
```diff
  Benchmark                                     Metric         Change
  ===================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.AddCircle      instructions   -62.6%
- ~Mathlib.Geometry.Manifold.Instances.Sphere   instructions     7.0%
```
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9024459973/job/24798346079)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9024459973/job/24798346387)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9024459973/job/24798346493)
nit: I think using `modify` here is slightly more idiomatic; perhaps as `modify ({ \. with at := subtractedMat })

I think you can write
```suggestion
    catch | .Unfeasible =>
```
here, on the premise that comments can be wrong in ways code can't.

The naming convention is that only types get `UpperCamelCase`, their inhabitants are `lowerCamelCase`.
```suggestion
| unfeasible : SimplexAlgoException
```
(though perhaps this should be `infeasible`, given [these trends](https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=infeasible%2Cunfeasible&year_start=1800&year_end=2019&corpus=en-2019&smoothing=3))

```suggestion
  /-- Array containing the basic variables' indexes -/
```

```suggestion
Note: we avoid using the `Matrix` in the root namespace because it is far more efficient to store matrix as its
```
which will create a link in the docs to the definition.

```suggestion
the `strictIndexes` are positive and `A v = 0`.
```

Could we have a comment here reminding the reader of the existence of FourierMotzkin?

(For maintainability, I'd like to be sure we can always "fall back" quickly and easily.)
I put a comment in the docstring
Could you rename `SimplexAlgo` to either `Simplex` or `SimplexAlgorithm`?

I'm not convinced the `currentRow` and `currentCol` parts of the `GaussM` monad is pulling its weight here; I'd be inclined to drop all these row operations, and:

* Make `findNonzeroRow` take `curRow` and `curCol`
* Use `let mut row` and `let mut col` in `getTableImp`
* Change `GaussM` to `StateM <| Matrix m n`

Happy to let another reviewer override me.

**[imports]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.SimplexAlgorithm.Datatypes import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.SimplexAlgorithm.Gauss import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.SimplexAlgorithm.PositiveVector import Mathlib.Tactic.Linarith.SimplexAlgorithm.SimplexAlgorithm ```

```suggestion
      -- If needed, we can switch back to the Fourier-Motzkin generator using
      -- let oracle := cfg.oracle.getD FourierMotzkin.produceCertificate
      let oracle := cfg.oracle.getD SimplexAlgorithm.produceCertificate
```
I don't think we need this; we can already switch back with `linarith (config := { oracle := some .fourierMotzkin})` (after the changes I just pushed to fix dot notation.
The new algorithm is about 5x slower here than the old one was.

It's likely due to the large size of the matrix (about 100 rows and columns), which is actually sparse (only 6% of the entries are non-zero). This is typical of `nlinarith`, and, in the next PR, I'll make it possible to use sparse matrices in the algorithm.
Can you edit the comment in this file to explain that simplex is likely slower here due to the use of dense matrices?
Done :)

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Tactic/Linarith): Simplex Algorithm oracle

source.title: linarith can no longer solve a simple problem
